text: I'm the income what you're hearing is a
woman singing in Quechua that's the Inca
language still spoken in this remote
corner of Peru san cristobal de la Paz
is about 13,000 feet above sea level
it's home to about 500 people who heard
Yama's in alpacas it's also home to one
of the mysteries of archaeology the pass
is a community that owns an enormous
collection of key booze that's Frank
Solomon he's an anthropologist an expert
on Quechua culture at the University of
Wisconsin key booze he explains are
cryptic woven knots dating from the time
of the Incas with no written language
it's thought that the key booze were
their way of communicating across their
vast empire while most key booze are in
museums abroad the ones here are still
part of the culture not as
archaeological material out of the
ground but as patrimony as sacred
objects that they keep for their own use
in ritual and governance rituals often
involves sacrificing guinea pigs and
invoking deities any time that you're
not getting enough rain or that the
livestock are having trouble feeding or
staying healthy it's time to speak again
to the mountains that own their
resources kalasala fidencio Alejo
Falcone lives on the pastor's above the
pass and takes part in these rituals to
him the key booze of the villages
treasure we must remain here because
they burned our people will never
surrender them never not for anything
Frank Solomon explains it further they
feel that they must protect the quipu
collection for the same reason that we
feel we have to defend the physical
original of the Declaration of
Independence and the Constitution
the keepers have survived over the
